channel.title: Open Science Tools
channel.description: As the expectations of researchers increase, publishing reproducible scientific articles becomes essential. However, choosing tools for these tasks can be difficult. This course aims to guide researchers through these challenges by introducing a workflow that utilizes Git, GitHub, and the Quarto scientific and technical publishing system for collaborative scientific writing.

item.title: Give me a title
item.dc:creator: First Last
item.description:
Scholarly writing

Scholarly articles require much more detail in their front matter than simply a title and an author. Quarto provides a rich set of YAML metadata keys to describe these details

Front Matter

  1. Add a title to the document

  2. Replace the values under author for name, orcid, email, and affiliation with your own

  3. Edit the abstract to be a short description of your article

  4. Render the document to see the changes

Citations

  1. Add the citation key for the paper “‘My flight arrives at 5 am, can you pick me up?’: The gatekeeping burden of the african academic” as an in-text reference to the sentence below

In ___, the authors describe how visitors still expect a personal pick-up, despite the availability of taxi services.

  1. Add the citation key for the paper “‘The rich will always be able to dispose of their waste’: a view from the frontlines of municipal failure in Makhanda, South Africa” as a citation at the end of the sentence below.

Inequality underpins waste management systems, structuring who can or cannot access services ___.

Bibliographies

Your folder already contains a references.bib file. One way of creating this bibliography is by exporting a collection in Zotero reference management tool. However, references can also be added by searching from within RStudio.

As part of the preparation your an article by (Wilson et al., 2017).

  1. Place at the cursor at the end of the sentence above and remove the placeholder

  2. In visual editing mode, click Insert -> Citation

  3. Open the Crossref dialogue on the left

  4. Search for “good enough practices in scientific computing”

  5. Click on the reference to highlight it

  6. Click on the `+` button at the top right of the reference

  7. Click Insert on the bottom right of the page

  8. Render the document to see the changes

References

Wilson, G., Bryan, J., Cranston, K., Kitzes, J., Nederbragt, L., & Teal, T. K. (2017). Good enough practices in scientific computing. PLOS Computational Biology, 13(6), e1005510. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1005510

Reuse

https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/

Citation

BibTeX citation:
@online{last2023,
  author = {Last, First},
  title = {Give Me a Title},
  date = {2023-10-17},
  url = {https://www.example.com},
  langid = {en},
  abstract = {The abstract will be placed here. Breaks can be added by
    hitting return on the keyboard.}
}
For attribution, please cite this work as:
Last, F. (2023, October 17). Give me a title. My Blog. https://www.example.com
